channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bit by Bit, Whole Foods Gets an Amazon Touch
item.media:description: The Whole Foods flagship store, in Austin, Tex., has many of the new changes Amazon has made to the grocery chain.
item.media:credit: Drew Anthony Smith for The New York Times
item.description: It has been six months since Amazon took over Whole Foods for $13.4 billion. Here are a handful of notable changes Amazon has made to Whole Foods so far.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Spotify Files to Go Public on the New York Stock Exchange
item.media:description: Daniel Ek, the chief executive and a co-founder of Spotify. According to a company filing, Spotify had nearly $5 billion in revenue last year, up 39 percent from the year before.
item.description: Instead of a traditional public offering, the streaming music service will pursue a direct listing of its shares, which will be traded under the ticker symbol SPOT.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO

item.title: Tech Fix: Should You Get a Cheaper Phone? Be Sure to Look Into the Camera
item.media:description: George Zhao of Huawei discussing its Honor smartphones in London in December. The $200 Honor 7X was a runner-up budget pick by Wirecutter.
item.media:credit: Joe Maher/Getty Images for Honor UK
item.description: The most popular smartphones can cost $700 or more. But for roughly $200, you can have a model that isn’t cutting edge but is plenty capable.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: Tech We’re Using: Mexico Has Its Spyware. A Reporter Has a Few Phones to Juggle.
item.media:description: Azam Ahmed, the chief of The New York Times’s Mexico bureau, talking with an editor on a satellite phone while reporting from a remote Haitian village after Hurricane Matthew in 2016.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Our Mexico bureau chief, Azam Ahmed, uses various strategies to keep communications safe while reporting, including the low-tech tactic of in-person meetings.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Facebook Lets Ads Bare a Man’s Chest. A Woman’s Back Is Another Matter.
item.media:description: Facebook mistakenly told Krista Venero, who writes under the pen name K.L. Montgomery, that the top image violated its policy against adult content in ads. The second ad, which she pointed out to Facebook, does not.
item.description: Advertisers, especially smaller ones, complain of inconsistency and gender bias in the process that determines whether images are rejected for being sexually suggestive.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI and SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Trilobites: When Did Americans Stop Marrying Their Cousins? Ask the World’s Largest Family Tree
item.media:description: A blank family record from 1889.
item.description: Researchers assembled 5 million family trees using data from the website Geni.com to test several genetic and historical hypotheses.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Facebook to End News Feed Experiment in 6 Countries That Magnified Fake News
item.media:description: A booth at Facebook’s annual F8 developer conference in San Jose, Calif. The social network is stopping the experiment known as Explore, which separates news publishers from its main site.
item.description: The social network is ending Explore, an experiment in countries like Bolivia and Cambodia, where it had separated news and other publishers from its main site.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Rites of Passage: Hi Hi Good Morning Hi I Love You It’s Me
item.media:description: Illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times
item.description: WhatsApp connects families around the world in amazing ways, and also is a complete nightmare.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Tech Tip: How to Get Your Tweet Fix Now That Twitter’s Mac App Is Dead
item.description: Twitter will stop supporting its official app for Mac computers in mid-March, but you can find alternatives that offer plenty of features.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Why This Tech Executive Says Her Plan to Disrupt Education Is Different
item.media:description: Students at Lumineer Academy in Williamstown, Australia. The school uses an alternative learning model based on technology businesses.
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.description: Susan Wu, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, has opened a school in Australia.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Subpoenas Signal S.E.C. Crackdown on Initial Coin Offerings
item.media:description: Jay Clayton, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has said he asked his agency to go after companies that sell virtual currencies and the “gatekeepers” that help them.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Regulators are believed to have demanded information from as many as 80 people and companies associated with virtual currencies.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Is Bitcoin a Waste of Electricity, or Something Worse?
item.media:description: Tom Pillsworth, right, whose company operates and maintains Bitcoin machines located at a former paper warehouse in Plattsburgh, N.Y.
item.media:credit: Jacob Hannah for The New York Times
item.description: America has a productivity problem. One explanation may be the growing use of real resources to make virtual products.
item.dc:creator: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM

item.title: Facebook’s “Cat and Mouse Game”
item.description: Facebook C.T.O. Mike Schroepfer, speaking at The New York Times’s New Work Summit, explained how artificial intelligence helps the social media giant tackle the constantly evolving threat of dangerous and offensive content.

item.title: Paul Allen Wants to Teach Machines Common Sense
item.media:description: “To make real progress in A.I., we have to overcome the big challenges in the area of common sense,” said Paul Allen, who founded Microsoft in the 1970s with Bill Gates.
item.media:credit: Béatrice de Géa for The New York Times
item.description: The Microsoft co-founder will give $125 million to his nonprofit research lab to help develop technology that adds common sense to artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ

item.title: Tech Tip: You Dumped Facebook. So Why Does It Keep Sending You Emails?
item.description: If you’re still receiving “Welcome back to Facebook” messages, you may not have fully closed your account on the social network.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Flying Taxis May Be Years Away, but the Groundwork Is Accelerating
item.media:description: A prototype from Lilium, a German air taxi company that has raised $90 million from investors.
item.description: As in the early days of self-driving cars, companies are digging in now so they aren’t left behind later. Just don’t call the aircraft “flying cars.”
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Amazon Buys Ring, Maker of Smart Home Products
item.media:description: Amazon was said to have paid more than $1 billion for Ring, which is best known for a doorbell with a security camera inside and is based in Santa Monica, Calif.
item.description: Amazon has made home automation a major focus because of the success of its Echo family of products.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: State of the Art: The Sublime and Scary Future of Cameras With A.I. Brains
item.description: A new generation of cameras like Google’s new Clips device can understand what they see, creating intriguing and sometimes eerie possibilities.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Tech Tip: How to Monitor Cellular Data Use for Apps
item.description: To see which apps are grabbing the most data, peek into your device’s settings or fire up a software meter.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: On Technology: How Tiny Red Dots Took Over Your Life
item.description: Technologists are starting to fret that their creations are too addictive. They could start by doing something about the dots.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: California Scraps Safety Driver Rules for Self-Driving Cars
item.media:description: A driverless car on the streets of Mountain View, Calif. The state’s Department of Motor Vehicles said it is eliminating a requirement for autonomous vehicles to have a person in the driver’s seat.
item.description: The new regulations in Silicon Valley’s home state are expected to help the wider deployment of autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can the United States Search Data Overseas?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Jeffrey Henson Scales/The New York Times, images by, Darko Labor/EyeEm, Andrzej Wojcick/Science Photo Library, and Martin Barraud, via Getty Images
item.description: A Supreme Court case asks where the government’s right to examine digital evidence ends.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG A. NEWMAN

item.title: Kratsios: Let's Not Rest on Our Laurels
item.description: Speaking at The New York Times’s New Work Summit, Deputy U.S. Chief Technology Officer Michael Kratsios said the U.S. is still leading China in artificial intelligence, but needs to keep pushing ahead.

item.title: Richard Yu on Huawei Phone Restrictions
item.description: Huawei C.E.O. Consumer Business Group Richard Yu spoke about challenges of expanding his product into the U.S. market at The New York Times’s 2018 New Work Summit.

item.title: Tech Tip: Wireless (or Wired) Chromebook Printing
item.description: Those lightweight laptops running Google’s Chrome OS operating system can work with certain types of printer models.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Women in Cryptocurrencies Push Back Against ‘Blockchain Bros’
item.description: Cryptocurrencies and blockchain were meant to be great equalizers. Instead, women are finding that the gold rush is already stacked against them.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: How Companies Scour Our Digital Lives for Clues to Our Health
item.description: An emerging field, digital phenotyping, tries to assess people’s well-being based on their interactions with digital devices.
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER

item.title: Tech Envisions the Ultimate Start-Up: An Entire City
item.description: Silicon Valley wants to save cities. What could go wrong?
item.dc:creator: EMILY BADGER

item.title: Facebook and Google Struggle to Squelch ‘Crisis Actor’ Posts
item.media:description: A video that said David Hogg, a survivor of the Parkland, Fla., school shooting, was a paid actor became a No. 1 trending video on YouTube this week.
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.description: The tech companies vowed this week to stamp out conspiracy videos and misinformation on the Parkland, Fla., shooting. So far, they are falling short.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS and SHEERA FRENKEL
item.category: Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School (Parkland, Fla)

item.title: Dropbox Files for I.P.O., and Other ‘Unicorns’ Are Watching
item.media:description: Drew Houston, chief executive of Dropbox, which was most recently valued at about $10 billion by private-market investors.
item.description: The online file storage company, part of a group of highly valued start-ups known as “unicorns,” said it planned to raise up to $500 million in a public offering.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: Plumbing Problem Shows Powers and Limits of 3 Tax Programs
item.media:description: The leading online tax-return preparation programs make the routine parts of doing your taxes easy. But when complexities arise, you can still wind up fretting over Internal Revenue Service rules.
item.description: TurboTax, H&R Block and TaxAct all make filing easier, but they left our reviewer confused about what the I.R.S. would accept and what it would not.
item.dc:creator: TIM GRAY

item.title: Tech Tip: Organizing Pictures With Words
item.description: Tagging photos with keywords allows you to quickly search for specific images based on what is shown in them.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Bits: Dai and Jack’s Week in Tech: Don’t Trust the Internet
item.media:description: Jack Nicas, The Times’s new Apple reporter, visited the new Apple campus this week.
item.description: Why the internet is full of lies and why the problem isn’t getting fixed are big questions few in the tech industry seem eager to answer.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and JACK NICAS

item.title: U.S. Blocks a Chinese Deal Amid Rising Tensions Over Technology
item.media:description: Robots at an automobile plant in the Chinese city of Hangzhou. China wants to use state support and overseas acquisitions to dominate high-tech fields like big data, advanced robotics and electric cars.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: A maker of chip-testing equipment, Xcerra, said it was walking away from a proposed sale to a Chinese group because of regulatory concerns.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG
